node.title: China Could Have 1,000 Nuclear Warheads by 2030, Pentagon Says
node.alt: Chinese military vehicles carrying DF-41 ballistic missiles roll during a parade in Beijing in 2019 to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China.
node.description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called Beijing the “No. 1” nation-state military challenger to the United States.
node.content: ["WASHINGTON \u2014 China is continuing to strengthen its strategic nuclear arsenal and could have 1,000 nuclear warheads by 2030, according to a new Defense Department report released Wednesday.", "The Pentagon\u2019s annual report to Congress on China\u2019s military might estimates that China could have 700 deliverable nuclear warheads by 2027 and 1,000 three years later. In addition, it warns that China has \u201cpossibly already established a nascent nuclear triad with the development of a nuclear capable air-launched ballistic missile and improvement of its ground and sea-based nuclear capabilities.\u201d", "Even with the accelerated nuclear expansion, Beijing is still behind the United States, with its nuclear stockpile of 5,550 warheads, and Russia, which has 6,255, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, an independent organization. China has about 350 nuclear warheads, the organization said.", "But Beijing has refused to join arms control talks, arguing that its nuclear arsenal is far smaller than those of the world\u2019s two major nuclear powers. At the same time, it has pursued a broad military modernization program that has raised questions about its intentions.", "The American military\u2019s most senior officer said on Wednesday that he views China as the \u201cNo. 1\u201d nation-state military challenger to the United States. The comments, by Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, during a moderated discussion at the Aspen Security Forum, came a week after he characterized China\u2019s recent launch of a hypersonic weapon designed to evade American defenses as a near \u201cSputnik\u201d moment, in an allusion to the Soviet launch of a satellite in 1957, which spooked the American public and helped spur the nuclear arms race during the Cold War.", "China, General Milley said on Wednesday, is \u201cclearly challenging us regionally, and their aspiration is to challenge us globally.\u201d He added that \u201cthey have a China dream, and they want to challenge the so-called liberal rules-based order.\u201d", "Asked if the United States could \u201cmatch\u201d China\u2019s hypersonic capability, General Milley declined to answer. But he said later that \u201cif we in the United States don\u2019t do a fundamental change ourselves, then we will be on the wrong side of a conflict.\u201d", "General Milley said the United States \u201cabsolutely\u201d could defend Taiwan from an attack by China if \u2014 and that part is a big if \u2014 political leaders decided to do so. Such a decision by any American president would be a huge shift, since the United States for decades has followed a policy of \u201cstrategic ambiguity\u201d that leaves open the question of whether the United States would back Taiwan in a military conflict with China. General Milley did not veer from that policy on Wednesday.", "He said he did not expect China to take military action against Taiwan in the next 24 months. But when pressed on whether the Pentagon could defend Taiwan, he said that \u201cwe absolutely have the capability to do all kinds of things around the world, to include that, if required.\u201d", "On China\u2019s reunification with Taiwan, he added that \u201cthe Chinese are clearly and unambiguously building the capability to provide those options to the national leadership if they choose at some point in the future.\u201d China considers Taiwan a breakaway province.", "China\u2019s most recent defense strategy, released in 2019, said it would keep its \u201cnuclear capabilities at the minimum level required for national security.\u201d Beijing has also vowed not to use nuclear weapons first or against any non-nuclear state.", "Perhaps surprisingly, the Pentagon report makes little mention of the coronavirus pandemic, which began in China in 2019 and spread globally, killing more than 5 million people so far and infecting millions more.", "The Pentagon report also backs General Milley\u2019s account of his phone calls with his Chinese counterpart in late 2020 to reassure China that the United States under President Donald J. Trump had no intention of attacking. According to the report, the calls came at the direction of Mr. Trump\u2019s secretary of defense at the time, Mark T. Esper, whom Mr. Trump would later fire."]
